bibl.title: Letter from Christopher Reed to [Jefferson Randolph Kean?], May 31, 1903

div1.p: Christopher Reed gives his account of Walter Reed's childhood.

div1.head: Letter from Christopher Reed to [Jefferson Randolph Kean?], May 31, 1903
div1.opener:
Acknowledged you
June 6 th /03
by C.L.
C. REED
ATTORNEY AND COUNSELOR AT LAW
317 COMMERCIAL BUILDING
ST. LOUIS, MO.
May 31/03
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
My dear Sir:-
div1.p:
I have just thought of a humorous
incident in Walter's life that I send
to you for what it may be worth-

He was always very happy & social
& when a little boy of 7 he & myself well
attended school (private one) at Farmville
Prince Edward Co Va where my father then
mailed (& where he is now buried) In the school
was a wooden board painted on one
side “out” on the other “in”- This was
to notify pupils that when they saw the
side marked “out” that some one already
enjoyed the privilege of being out & that they
must wait till the side “in” could
be seen- Walter was so fond of heay
& so fond of his little friends & so quick
to master his “lessons” that he remained
out of the school room nearly all of the
time, so much so that whenever the the board
was turned “out” the students would
say “little Walter Reed is out again.”
One day after the teacher (now Rev. Geo. E Booker
of Va) noticed Walter's propensity
to stay out he said to him
as he slipped back quietly
into the school room smiling:-
“Walter, you remind me
of the boy, who went to see
his grandmother twice a
year & staid 6 mos. each time”
My mother always enjoyed
to hear this story- He was
affectionate & social in his
nature & he wanted to be
out with Nature & the little
friends he loved, and every
boy in school small &
big loved him as a brother,
for he had the sweetest laugh
when a child I ever heard
